awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Modeling of Secondary and Tertiary Gravity Waves from Orographic Gravity Wave Forcing and Comparison with Satellite Observations
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative project involving both NWRA and Hampton University supports a study of atmospheric dynamics within the region of the Earth's atmosphere that is not accessible by low Earth orbiting satellites or by balloons. Air that is associated with the wind flow over mountainous terrain is disturbed by a class of 'primary' atmospheric gravity waves (GWs) that is called 'mountains waves' (MWs). These waves break or reach critical levels in the lower or middle atmosphere at altitudes below 70 km. This process not only creates small-scale secondary GWs with horizontal wavelengths considerably less than that of the MWs, but also creates horizontal 'body forces' (i.e., horizontal accelerations localized in space and time). These in turn are thought to excite a broad spectrum of secondary GWs with horizontal wavelengths larger than that of the MWs. The main objective of the research is to quantify to the extent possible the effect that secondary and tertiary GWs from MW attenuation has on the thermosphere (the neutral atmosphere above 200 km) via this multi-step coupling process. The research includes a unique combination of detailed, targeted modeling combined with data analyses studies. A graduate student associated with Hampton University would participate in the research work described.

Several different simulations would be used in sequence to simulate the entire process. Data from the Gravity field and steady-state Ocean Circulation Explorer (GOCE) satellite would be analyzed to extract GWs parameters observed for specific regions on Earth, and the simulations will be compared to these satellite observations. The project will involve applying these results to the study of MWs to investigate the extent to which secondary and tertiary waves that affect the thermosphere are produced. The research if successful should significantly advance the research community's understanding of the process of momentum transfer from orographic forcing to the thermosphere via GWs in this multi-step coupling process. This research is expected to lead to a much better appreciation of the variability and structure of the thermosphere from these processes (i.e., space weather from below) thus helping to achieve a significant broader impact because a predictive capability might possibly be developed for such thermospheric wave structures were this momentum transfer process be understood much more completely as a result of research work represented by this award.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project is to study secondary and tertiary gravity waves from Andes mountain orographic gravity wave forcing. The research activity at Hampton University is to analyze thermospheric gravity waves in satellite data, GOCE and CHAMP neutral density and cross-track wind measurements. The most significant finding from this work is the clear evidence of gravity waves identified over Andes Mountain and Antarcitica Pennisula in the thermosphere. Because orographic gravity waves are not expected to penetrate higher than the mesosphere, the physics behind the observation of those thermospheric gravity waves is secondary and tertiary wave generation from primary wave dissipation. Meanwhile, waves in the thermosphere can also be excited by auroral heating. During geomagnetic active periods, thermospheric gravity waves primarily coincide with the auroral ovel. We also find that these thermospheric gravity waves are sesonal dependent. This award resulted in ~20 papers for 4 years.

The intellectual merit addressed in this project is mainly the morphology and climatology of satellite derived gravity waves. Comparing to modeled secondary and tertiary gravity waves by HIAMCM model at NWRA, the physics process of higher order wave generation from primary wave dissipation will be elucidated. This is the frontier of gravity wave researches and expands the field from the mesosphere to the thermosphere. Gravity wave induced disturbances, or the so-called thermosphere traveling disturbances, could cause disturbances to satellite drag in the LEO orbit. 

 

In addition to the contribution to future satellite drag calculations and orbit prediction, this project has partially supported a PhD student, Mr. Shuang Xu, at Hampton University, a HBCU, for 4 years, including stipend and tuition. Mr. Xu is expected to graduate in summer 2023. The analysis results from this project will be an essential part of his dissertation. This contributes the training of the next generation of young space scientist. The results of this work has been disseminated at Hampton University student symposium, an underrepresented group of student.
